# 🎯 Essential Elements

These are **required** for a professional finish:

## ✅ Add a Cover Image

Place this right below your main heading:

``` markdown
![Cover Image](images/cover.png)
```

If you don’t have an image, you can use a free placeholder:

``` markdown
![Cover](https://via.placeholder.com/800x200?text=How+Markdown+Works)
```

## ✅ Build a Table of Contents

Link to key sections within your README using anchor links or cross-file
links.

Example:

``` markdown
## Table of Contents

- [Introduction](#your-mission)
- [Headings](#️-headings)
- [Emphasis](#️-emphasis-italic-bold)
- [Code](#️-code)
- [Tables](tables.md)
- [Images](images.md)
- [Reflections](#-reflections)
```

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# 📚 Write Your Tutorial Sections

Each section must: 1. Start with a heading (e.g.,
`## How Headings Work`) 2. Explain in your own words 3. Show example
code using triple backticks (```` ``` ````) 4. Show the rendered result
after the code block

# 🚀 Advanced Markdown

## ✏️ Badges

> 🔗 [shields.io](https://shields.io)

**Example badge code:**

```` markdown
```
![GitHub repo size](https://img.shields.io/github/repo-size/yourname/how-markdown-works)
```
````

## ✏️ Collapsible Sections

**Example:**

```` markdown
```
<details>
<summary>Click to reveal</summary>

Hidden content inside.

</details>
```
````

## ✏️ Task Lists

```` markdown
```
- [x] Done
- [ ] To do
```
````

## ✏️ Tip Blocks (Callouts)

> 🔗 [GitHub Callouts
> Info](https://github.blog/changelog/2022-05-19-markdown-task-lists-tables-and-more-are-now-supported-in-comments/)

GitHub supports **info boxes** using blockquotes and emojis:

**Example:**

``` markdown
> ℹ️ **Tip:** You can preview your Markdown as you write by clicking the "Preview" tab above.
```

Which renders like: \> ℹ️ **Tip:** You can preview your Markdown as you
write by clicking the "Preview" tab above.

You can use emojis like 💡, ❗, ✅ to signal purpose.
